text: In this project, a "state" is understood as a temporally bounded configuration of explicit arguments, assumptions, and distinctions.
Large language models are used to externalize and vary arguments and assumptions, so that they can be inspected, compared, and revised.
No claim in the Matrix is treated as authoritative; inclusion records an articulated position with provenance and time, not correctness.
A central failure mode is implicitness: when assumptions or scopes remain unstated, disagreement becomes unreadable and the state becomes structurally unstable.
